intro: Polyosma nullii, commonly known as the Null Island holly, is a rare and endemic plant species found in the remote regions of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Ericaceae, which includes heathers and other shrubs adapted to nutrient-poor soils. The plant is characterized by its evergreen leaves, which are typically small, leathery, and arranged in a spiral pattern around the stem. It produces small, white or pale pink flowers that bloom in spring, followed by dark blue berries. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Polyosma nullii is considered a vulnerable species facing threats from habitat loss and climate change.
